title: FPS drops on my new computer
body:
I recently just built my new computer, it consists of an i5 4690, 8gb 1600mhz ram and a gtx 970.

With maxed settings I sit at around 350 fps, during last game, it slowly kept dropping.. until it reached around 150fps, by the end of the game, it was 120fps and it dipped to as low as 60 at one point..

I've checked my cpu temperature and its running fine (so I'm guessing it hasn't had to do much work at all, come on.. its league, also MSI afterburner is showing me that my gfx card only had to use a max of 36% power.. and a max temp of 61 degrees..


soo, my computer is more than capable to play league at 200-300 fps + for a week straight. Whats up?

replies.body: Question: Did you build your PC yourself or did you buy it pre built?

I actually haves the same problem, I've been fiddling around with it for weeks. I too have a very similar rig with the exception of i7 to your i5, and my gpu sits at around 30-40 degrees. I have a constant 200-300 Fps with maxed out setting but then ever couple of minutes it will drop to about 10 Fps for a couple of second and then right back to the constant 200-300. Like you using msi afterburner shows my gpu usage is never over 40%. Last night I suspect I fixed it, I've only had one game since I "fixed" it so I can't be sure that it's completely gone. But in that game the lowest Fps I can remember having is 120. Here is what I did, I actually did both and one fixed the problem i don't know which one though.
1. If you have google chrome installed. In Google chrome go Settings > advanced settings; untick both "use hardware acceleration when available" and "use application while Google chrome is closed".
2. Right click on your desktop and select Nvidia control panel. Go to 3D settings > manage 3D settings on the side. Then find the program settings tab. Find "League of Legends" under the program to customise drop down list and click "restore". Don't worry if you can't click restore it just means they're already set to the default settings. Now go to where it says "select the preferred graphics processor for this program:" and select "high performance NVIDIA processor". Now scroll down and change the following settings; 
CUDA - GPUs and change it to "use these GPUs - GeForceGTX970"
Power management mode "prefer maximum performance"

I think this is all the changes I made to mine, I can check and confirm when I get home tonight. Also make sure your graphics drivers are up to date.

I'm tentative at saying this is a solution because I haven't confirmed its a complete fix for me but from what I've found it helps. Good luck with your system and I hope this helps. {{champion:201}}

Have you ever ran firestrike? (3dmark) ?

60 degrees at idle is a bit high, i would change the MSI Afterburner fan curve. This is what mine is set at, you probably don't need to go so heavy like i did but i like having my GPU at a safe temp as to not lose potential performance. I would try and keep your GPU temp under 50 degrees if you can. Also if your GPU is at 60 degrees at idle you should probably check your CPU temps, having a high CPU temp could force your CPU to throttle itself back to protect against damage meaning your not getting the best performance.
